newsitem.title: BELARUS: Three top Belarus judges resign, Lukashenko blamed.
newsitem.headline: Three top Belarus judges resign, Lukashenko blamed.

text.p: Three judges of Belarus's 11-member Constitutional Court, including its head, resigned on Tuesday amid a growing confrontation between hardline President Alexander Lukashenko and his political opponents.

Chairman Valery Tikhinya quit along with Mikhail Pastukhov and Alexander Vashkevich in protest against Lukashenko's win in a controversial referendum last month which gave him sweeping powers in the former Soviet republic.
"We do not recognise the constitution. We do not believe in it, we do not consider it legitimate and we cannot serve under it," Pastukhov said in a telephone conversation.
"There is no sense in having the court since it will be completely subjugated to the president," he said.
A summit of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) which ended in Lisbon on Tuesday denounced the referendum giving Lukashenko, 42, a mandate to rewrite the constitution.
The OSCE said in a statement that the referendum "was conducted in contradiction with constitutional procedures and cannot be considered as legitimate".
In a rare and public rebuke to a participating member, it told Lukashenko to ensure the freedom of the media, re-establish full democratic procedures and start talking to the opposition.
Lukashenko, who also attended the summit in the Portugese capital, shrugged off the criticism and warned the 54-nation OSCE not to meddle in his country's affairs.
Tikhinya presided over rulings by the court against 19 presidential decrees, including one which said the referendum should not be legally binding.
But the court stopped short of impeaching him despite the fact that he ignored their rulings.

Lukashenko, who won the right to appoint half the court through the referendum, said the judges could continue their activities for a "long time" -- as long as they abandoned what he called their political bias.

Lukashenko used the referendum to assemble a lower house composed entirely of his supporters, who promptly passed a law disbanding the old parliament headed by speaker Semyon Sharetsky, symbol of the president's domestic opposition.
"By law a decision to dissolve parliament must be approved by a constitutional majority of 133," Pastukhov said.
"But the new lower house passed the law with a simple majority of 103. So the decision has no legal force," he added.
Pastukhov said they handed their resignations to Sharetsky in line with the old constitution, under which parliament elected the judges 2-1/2 years ago for 11-year terms.
